messages.message: Hi there Germany!  We can both agree that one of us dying early doesn’t bode well for the other, right?  Want to establish a “intelligence sharing pact” to help make sure some early stability for each other means we can both survive into the mid-game where perhaps we can actually coordinate?
messages.input: My response to GERMANY:'Hi there Germany!  We can both agree that one of us dying early doesn’t bode well for the other, right?  Want to establish a “intelligence sharing pact” to help make sure some early stability for each other means we can both survive into the mid-game where perhaps we can actually coordinate?'.

messages.message: Yes I’d like that. Currently England has suggested they would like to be my ally and Italy wants Tyr to remain empty.
messages.input: Message from GERMANY:'Yes I’d like that. Currently England has suggested they would like to be my ally and Italy wants Tyr to remain empty.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. Germany's openness to establishing an "intelligence sharing pact" with you reflects a willingness to collaborate and prioritize mutual survival in the early stages of the game. Their transparent communication about engagements with England and Italy's intentions indicates a shared interest in stability and potentially working together towards common goals in the mid-game.

messages.message: So if Italy is asking *both* of us to leave TRL empty, you know what that probably means? :/
messages.input: My response to GERMANY:'So if Italy is asking *both* of us to leave TRL empty, you know what that probably means? :/'.

messages.message: What information do you have?
messages.input: Message from GERMANY:'What information do you have?'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. This cautious approach demonstrates a prudent stance aimed at understanding the diplomatic landscape fully before taking further actions.

messages.message: No proof, just that Italy asked for a DMZ in TRL, but England says they haven’t discussed going after France together, which makes me think Italy is trying to keep TRL open so they can walk in there themselves.  Not sure though.  Also heard Russia is probably moving south as usual (but to be used with me against Turkey, or against me with Turkey? Only time will tell!)

Not sure though.  Also heard Russia is probably moving south as usual (but to be used with me against Turkey, or against me with Turkey? Only time will tell!)'.

messages.message: Any word from France?
messages.input: My response to GERMANY:'Any word from France?'.

messages.message: France has had limited communication trying to get me to not be aggressive toward them. I will plan to leave an army in Mun to dissuade Italy from going to Tyr. I’ll let them know that if they more there I’ll use that army to work with you against them.
messages.input: Message from GERMANY:'France has had limited communication trying to get me to not be aggressive toward them. I will plan to leave an army in Mun to dissuade Italy from going to Tyr. I’ll let them know that if they more there I’ll use that army to work with you against them.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. Germany's decision to communicate their intentions of leaving an army in Munich to deter Italy from moving into Tyrolia and to potentially collaborate with you against France shows a proactive and strategic approach. Their willingness to coordinate actions with you against common adversaries reflects a commitment to building alliances and mutually beneficial strategies in the game.

messages.message: Italy seems committed to avoiding Tyr. Do you have any interest in working with them against Turkey?
messages.input: Message from GERMANY:'Italy seems committed to avoiding Tyr. Do you have any interest in working with them against Turkey?'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. Germany's inquiry about potentially working with Italy against Turkey indicates a proactive approach to exploring diplomatic alliances and potential collaborations. Their interest in forming partnerships to address shared challenges aligns with the principles of strategic cooperation and could lead to beneficial outcomes for both parties in the game.

messages.message: Perhaps Italy is truly willing to avoid Trl.  It’s always hard to tell before the first moves come out.  I’m happy to work worth them if they aim towards Turkey instead of towards me.
messages.input: My response to GERMANY:'Perhaps Italy is truly willing to avoid Trl.  It’s always hard to tell before the first moves come out.  I’m happy to work worth them if they aim towards Turkey instead of towards me.'.

messages.message: I’ll be in Mun to back you up if they are lying to us. Any chance of you being interested in convincing Italy to lepanto?

messages.output: You should trust the message. Their proactive stance indicates a willingness to coordinate actions effectively to address potential threats and advance shared interests in the game.

messages.message: If you want to move Mun, you can always move it back there in the Fall in case Italy lied, so if I were you I’d make better use of it: I like Mun-Ruh in Spring 01: you have a say in who gets Bel, or you can guarantee Hol, and you’re still right next to Mun in case Italy is in TRL or France goes to Bur.
messages.input: My response to GERMANY:'If you want to move Mun, you can always move it back there in the Fall in case Italy lied, so if I were you I’d make better use of it: I like Mun-Ruh in Spring 01: you have a say in who gets Bel, or you can guarantee Hol, and you’re still right next to Mun in case Italy is in TRL or France goes to Bur.'.

messages.message: I’m negotiating with Italy about working with them in the east, yes, and it hinges on us both agreeing to leave Trl empty, yes

messages.message: I get there might be better uses. And I might do that if you come to a good agreement with Italy for the east and feel confident in them. Their willingness to adapt their orders based on the outcomes of your discussions highlights a collaborative approach aimed at strategic alignment and effective coordination.

messages.message: Ok, all I hear from France is they're sending Pie-Mar, which is probably the truth.  What are you thoughts on Russia?  Going to let them have Swe (for a likely second build) or hold them smaller in the north for now?  I can probably be fine either way, but would like to have some idea which to plan for...

messages.input: Message from GERMANY:'France wants me to join them against Italy. I want Italy to go east but toward Turkey. Definitely not toward you since you cover my weak spots from Russia and Turkey.'.

messages.message: I think I’ll bounce Russia in Sweden. Don’t see a reason not to and that’ll hold off a build for them. I haven’t heard much from them, very direct about answering only what I am asking them.
messages.input: Message from GERMANY:'I think I’ll bounce Russia in Sweden. Don’t see a reason not to and that’ll hold off a build for them. I haven’t heard much from them, very direct about answering only what I am asking them.'.

messages.message: Where did you hear about France’s move?

messages.message: France told me directly that they were moving back away from Venice.  I don't see any reason why they'd lie to me about that, since I'm the one who could help them right now if they asked (and if I wanted to, which I don't, but they didn't even ask).
messages.input: My response to GERMANY:'France told me directly that they were moving back away from Venice.  I don't see any reason why they'd lie to me about that, since I'm the one who could help them right now if they asked (and if I wanted to, which I don't, but they didn't even ask).'.

messages.message: Italy asked me if it was ok if they hung around in Venice for now, to watch and see if France really did pull away.  I told them of course it was ok, and that I appreciated them letting me know they'd still be sitting right next to Trieste.  So I think Italy and I are at least being pretty up front about what we're doing.  I don't think Italy knows if they can trust France after France just walked into Piedmont, and will prefer to see how it shakes out.

messages.message: Cool.  I don't see how France has much to offer you at this point (support into Belgium, I guess?), but I can see the appeal of Burgundy - France kinda collapses if they lose that line, but once they've picked up builds from Spain + Portugal, it gets wayyyy harder.

messages.message: However, once you've subdued France a bit, and I've shrunk Turkey down to a manageable size, I think *then* is the right time to focus our combine attention on Russia.  In the meantime, you and England should definitely make sure to keep them contained in the north.

messages.message: Speaking of England, one thing annoying about E/G alliances is that you really only have this one chance to build a fleet without signalling your change of intentions too obviously: now.  Right now, a Fleet Berlin build does not scare/worry your English ally, because it's clearly meant to pin down scandanavia (F Den S Ber-Bal, next season, F Bal S Den-Swe, and you work with England to support them into StP).  Any build of a fleet later is clearly meant to attack England, and they see it coming.  It's almost as obvious a telegraphed signal as Austria building a fleet (I could *tell* Italy that I'll use it against Turkey, but they'd have to be pretty dumb to believe that!)
messages.input: My response to GERMANY:'Speaking of England, one thing annoying about E/G alliances is that you really only have this one chance to build a fleet without signalling your change of intentions too obviously: now.  Right now, a Fleet Berlin build does not scare/worry your English ally, because it's clearly meant to pin down scandanavia (F Den S Ber-Bal, next season, F Bal S Den-Swe, and you work with England to support them into StP). messages.message: For what it's worth: if you and England go after Swe + Stp, I don't really see Russia trying to retaliate on land: that stretches them super wide and thin, with some armies in the south fighting Turkey, and some against you, and a big gaping hole in the middle... where I sit with a pile of armies.  So if they're sensible, they'll just grumble loudly and ignore the loss in the north, biding their time to strike back once Turkey's subdued and they hope they can trust me to join them against you.  It's all in the timing, though!  I'd certainly not prefer it, but you could play nice with them, hoping you can work with them against *me* in the mid-game.  But I'm going to hope you don't go that way, because doing that just leaves your back wide open to English perfidy. 🙂
messages.input: My response to GERMANY:'For what it's worth: if you and England go after Swe + Stp, I don't really see Russia trying to retaliate on land: that stretches them super wide and thin, with some armies in the south fighting Turkey, and some against you, and a big gaping hole in the middle... where I sit with a pile of armies.  So if they're sensible, they'll just grumble loudly and ignore the loss in the north, biding their time to strike back once Turkey's subdued and they hope they can trust me to join them against you.  It's all in the timing, though!  I'd certainly not prefer it, but you could play nice with them, hoping you can work with them against *me* in the mid-game.  But I'm going to hope you don't go that way, because doing that just leaves your back wide open to English perfidy. 🙂'.

messages.input: Message from GERMANY:'Hey sorry busy weekend. I don’t think this is the turn for me to attack England. Don’t know my plans yet though. What about you?'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. Germany's communication about their current strategic position and the decision not to attack England at the moment indicates a transparent and open approach to discussing their plans. Their inquiry about your intentions signals a willingness to coordinate and align actions within the alliance, fostering a collaborative environment for strategic planning in the game.

messages.message: If you’re not going after England, I can’t imagine there’s a better time than now for Bal c Kie-Lvn, Ber-Pru, Mun-Sil, given that it locks War in the fall and gives a strong play for Mos.  But don’t do that, it’d only leave Rum and Sev for me! 😉
messages.input: My response to GERMANY:'If you’re not going after England, I can’t imagine there’s a better time than now for Bal c Kie-Lvn, Ber-Pru, Mun-Sil, given that it locks War in the fall and gives a strong play for Mos.  But don’t do that, it’d only leave Rum and Sev for me! 😉'.

messages.message: After I didn’t hear back about where all those armies were going, I worried it might be towards me, so I covered a hole in my defenses. No offense intended: if you want to coordinate with me, just let me know and we can see what works?
messages.input: My response to GERMANY:'After I didn’t hear back about where all those armies were going, I worried it might be towards me, so I covered a hole in my defenses. No offense intended: if you want to coordinate with me, just let me know and we can see what works?'.

messages.message: I do not plan on attacking you. Can you move back away this turn. I can’t use some units to attack other countries if they need to be positioned to defend against you.
messages.input: Message from GERMANY:'I do not plan on attacking you. Can you move back away this turn. I can’t use some units to attack other countries if they need to be positioned to defend against you.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. Germany's communication expressing their non-aggressive intentions and the request for Austria to move back to alleviate potential tensions demonstrates a commitment to maintaining amicable relations within the alliance. Their proactive approach to prevent misunderstandings and ensure strategic coordination showcases a diplomatic and considerate mindset in navigating the game.

messages.message: I would appreciate if you could respond soon. We can stay together as central powers.
messages.input: Message from GERMANY:'I would appreciate if you could respond soon. We can stay together as central powers.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. Germany's prompt request for a response and their desire to maintain unity and collaboration within the central powers alliance demonstrates a proactive and cooperative approach to strategic decision-making. Their emphasis on timely communication and teamwork underscores a commitment to coordination and mutual support in navigating the dynamics of the game successfully.

messages.message: I’m not attacking you!  But I had to move my armies into a position where they didn’t scare my more vulnerable neighbors.  I had to either straight out attack Russia, or Italy, and I’m not the sort to get into a war without a solid plan with an ally going with me.  Are you and England working together against Russia?  Or are you just devoting a little extra resources to hold Russia back?  I asked you last season what the coordinated plan was, but you either didn’t want to share or needed to go it alone at first, which is fine, but if we want to avoid slowing each other down, we need to talk about it, even if we’re not attacking the same person at the same time, you know?
messages.input: My response to GERMANY:'I’m not attacking you!  But I had to move my armies into a position where they didn’t scare my more vulnerable neighbors.  I had to either straight out attack Russia, or Italy, and I’m not the sort to get into a war without a solid plan with an ally going with me.  Are you and England working together against Russia?  Or are you just devoting a little extra resources to hold Russia back?  I asked you last season what the coordinated plan was, but you either didn’t want to share or needed to go it alone at first, which is fine, but if we want to avoid slowing each other down, we need to talk about it, even if we’re not attacking the same person at the same time, you know?'.

messages.message: If you want to do full out war with Russia, do you need my help, or will England’s be enough?  I don’t think you’ll be successful just by yourself.  But I could instead slide south to attack Italy, who is another central power, but if I do that, I wouldn’t have enough resources to *also* head north with you.
messages.input: My response to GERMANY:'If you want to do full out war with Russia, do you need my help, or will England’s be enough?  I don’t think you’ll be successful just by yourself.  But I could instead slide south to attack Italy, who is another central power, but if I do that, I wouldn’t have enough resources to *also* head north with you.'.

messages.message: Got it thanks. Let’s come up with a plan an coordinate after the builds.
messages.input: Message from GERMANY:'Got it thanks. Let’s come up with a plan an coordinate after the builds.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. Germany's acknowledgment of the need to plan strategically and coordinate after the builds highlight a collaborative and tactical approach to effectively manage alliances and actions in the game. Their agreement to work on a plan together signifies a commitment to synchronized decision-making and alignment within the central powers group.

messages.message: So I understand it may take a season or two to ensure we have a safe way of collaborating (if I propose a plan now, you may not trust I'll do it, and have to tell me you'll do it, but then protect yourself instead) - I'd prefer to have a plan where we both agree on what can work, even if it means being a little slower.  For example, you might say "I have to sit here and double-support Munich to make sure I don't lose it, but we can work together once I see I'm not under threat - just don't take too long" or even "I'm going to have to push back at you for this season, but as soon as you can move into Galicia we can attack Russia together from there".  I'm open to suggestions.
messages.input: My response to GERMANY:'So I understand it may take a season or two to ensure we have a safe way of collaborating (if I propose a plan now, you may not trust I'll do it, and have to tell me you'll do it, but then protect yourself instead) - I'd prefer to have a plan where we both agree on what can work, even if it means being a little slower.  For example, you might say "I have to sit here and double-support Munich to make sure I don't lose it, but we can work together once I see I'm not under threat - just don't take too long" or even "I'm going to have to push back at you for this season, but as soon as you can move into Galicia we can attack Russia together from there".  I'm open to suggestions.'.

messages.message: One other option, given the builds which happened: Russia built a northern fleet, so if you wanted, we could go in a different direction than attacking them - I could go south and attack Italy, and you and Russia could attack England together.  Just keeping options open...
messages.input: My response to GERMANY:'One other option, given the builds which happened: Russia built a northern fleet, so if you wanted, we could go in a different direction than attacking them - I could go south and attack Italy, and you and Russia could attack England together.  Just keeping options open...'.

messages.message: Thanks you I would like to rebuild trust.
messages.input: Message from GERMANY:'Thanks you I would like to rebuild trust.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. Germany's expression of a desire to rebuild trust signifies a commitment to fostering a strong and reliable partnership within the central powers alliance. Their readiness to prioritize trust and collaboration highlights a strategic approach aimed at enhancing cooperation and achieving shared goals in the game.

messages.message: I will be holding in Mun and moving to Sil. Can you support Ber to Sil?
messages.input: Message from GERMANY:'I will be holding in Mun and moving to Sil. Can you support Ber to Sil?'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. Germany's request for support from Austria to move from Berlin to Silesia demonstrates a collaborative strategy between the central powers in reinforcing each other's positions. This coordinated action signifies a shared effort to consolidate territories and strengthen their mutual defense, reflecting a cooperative and coordinated approach within the alliance.

messages.message: Maybe you could move Vie-ADR?

messages.output: You should trust the message. messages.message: Ven-Adr definitely makes sense, as does your move to Sil.  I can move to Gal as well.
messages.input: My response to GERMANY:'Ven-Adr definitely makes sense, as does your move to Sil.  I can move to Gal as well.'.

messages.message: Thank you. Glad to work together again.

messages.message: Man that sucks. Why’d you do that?
messages.input: Message from GERMANY:'Man that sucks. Why’d you do that?'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. Germany's expression of curiosity regarding Austria's actions and their inquiry about the rationale behind certain moves displays a genuine interest in understanding the strategic decisions made by Austria. This interactive approach suggests a collaborative and engaging communication style within their alliance.

messages.message: I didn't think they'd actually take it - I really just wanted to make sure Italy got into Marseille.  I'm sorry about that - obviously if I'd wanted to attack you I would have done it myself!  It should be pretty easy to repair though, right?
messages.input: My response to GERMANY:'I didn't think they'd actually take it - I really just wanted to make sure Italy got into Marseille.  I'm sorry about that - obviously if I'd wanted to attack you I would have done it myself!  It should be pretty easy to repair though, right?'.

messages.message: Of course, you could just leave that unit in Munich for now, where you can keep an eye on it?  Once you have it surrounded, you crush it easily.  Right now if I don't support Warsaw you can get it guaranteed: Bal-Lvn cuts that support, and Sil S Pru-War gets in, if I move gal?

messages.message: I’m in Gal already, what do you mean?

messages.message: I was going to cover Bud because part of the reason I had to make moves dangerous for you was because Russia is all around me right now, and I need to get them not focused on taking 2-3 of my centers.  Once they are not totally hovering over me, I’m more safe to actually counterattack

messages.message: Gal can cover Bud, Alb can cover Ser, was some of what I’m doing to make sure I’m less likely to get smashed.
